" Zahi Hawass was not yet a member of Mubarak's cabinet when Parker profiled him in 2009, but was already prone to statements of his influence. Parker writes that when he met Zahi Hawass , his dominant conversational tone was rebuttal laced with invective and self-regard, built on the premise-it has some merit-that the international standing of Egypt is powerfully connected to the standing of Zahi Hawass . He has no doubt that his fame is a vital national asset.
